title: U.S. Treasury Yields Extend Steep Decline
summary: Yield on 10-year hits multimonth lows, highlighting concerns about the prospects for growth. Yields on U.S. government bonds reached fresh multimonth lows on Wednesday, reflecting investors' anxiety about the economic outlook and new concerns about the highly contagious Delta variant of Covid-19.

title: Search for Survivors in Miami-Area Collapsed Condo Is Called Off
summary: Rescue attempts are over with 86 missing; 54 people are confirmed dead. SURFSIDE, Fla.-The 14-day effort to find survivors of the collapsed condo was called off, with 86 people unaccounted for, Miami-Dade County Mayor Daniella Levine Cava said.

title: Theranos Founder Elizabeth Holmes Renews Fight to Constrain Prosecutors
summary: Lawyers for defunct startup's former CEO say their defense to criminal-fraud charges is hampered because a database with millions of blood-test results was dismantled. Lawyers for Theranos Inc. founder Elizabeth Holmes asked a federal judge to place new restrictions on the scope of evidence that prosecutors can present at her coming criminal-fraud trial, arguing her defense is hampered by the loss of a database with millions of blood-test results.

title: Bang & Olufsen CFO Sets Price Range for Purchases of Microchips
summary: The Danish electronics company is paying up to secure supply for its products. Nikolaj Wendelboe, the chief financial officer of Danish electronics company Bang & Olufsen A/S, in recent months has acquired a new responsibility: setting the price range for what the company is willing to pay for semiconductors, a tactic aimed at securing supply in a tight market.

title: The Teachers Unions Go Woke
summary: The NEA and AFT get behind progressive political indoctrination.. Parents didn't ask to be thrown into the trenches of America's culture war, but progressives aren't giving them a choice. Witness the way the national teachers unions are adopting woke values and pressing them into K-12 curriculums across the U.S.

title: Guilty Until Proven Innocent
summary: An FBI raid in Beverly Hills tests the limits of civil forfeiture.. When the FBI raided U.S. Private Vaults in Beverly Hills in March, it did so after the business had been indicted for conspiring to launder money, sell drugs and other crimes. But the FBI also took control of $86 million in cash and valuables it found in the safe deposit boxes of people who haven't been accused of a crime. Some of these folks have sued, and two weeks ago federal Judge R. Gary Klausner granted a temporary restraining order preventing the FBI from taking permanent legal title of the seized contents of the plaintiffs' boxes.

title: Delta Variant Is Dominant U.S. Covid-19 Strain
summary: Highly contagious variant is hitting hardest in parts of Midwest and South with lower vaccination rates. The highly transmissible Delta variant has become the dominant strain of the Covid-19 virus circulating in the U.S., according to federal data. It is spreading rapidly as communities loosen pandemic restrictions and officials struggle to reach unvaccinated people.

title: The Murder of Haiti's President
summary: Another chapter closes in a two-century-long story of institutional failure.. The assassination of Haitian President Jovenel Moïse-in the wee hours Wednesday morning at the presidential residence in Port-au-Prince-is heartbreaking for the nation. I write this not because of any special affinity for Moïse. Rather, his bloody death, by a bullet to the head according to one source, marks the end of another failed chapter in Haitian institution building.

title: China's Nuclear Silos and the Arms-Control Fantasy
summary: The Cold War is over, and Beijing is determined to amass an arsenal worthy of a superpower.. New satellite images published recently reveal that China is building more than 100 new nuclear missile silos in its western desert. Many American arms-control proponents, including the researchers who made the discovery and the Washington Post editorial board, immediately blamed China's actions on U.S. nuclear modernization plans and recommended that Washington make an arms-control deal with China to address this nuclear threat. This is both the wrong diagnosis and the wrong solution.

title: Kamala Harris vs. Greg Abbott on the Border
summary: Drugs and migrants, including trafficked children, continue to flow into Texas.. What's actually happening on the Texas-Mexico border?

title: Welcome to the Equity War
summary: Republicans are running on culture, while Democrats press economics.. President Biden outputs executive orders like a popcorn machine. His latest bucketful goes a long way toward clarifying the politics of our time.

title: 'The Aristocracy of Talent' Review: Getting Ahead, Falling Behind
summary: Succeeding in life by merit-and not because of background or parentage-seems eminently democratic. But the whole idea is under assault.. In 1958, the British sociologist Michael Young published "The Rise of the Meritocracy," a fictional narrative that imagined a world where leaders in business and government would be chosen on the basis of talent and effort rather than social status, wealth or power. But the book, which brought the word "meritocracy" into the English language, wasn't written to celebrate such a world. To the contrary, it was intended as a warning that those who fell behind in the competition to get ahead were likely to resent the new elite and would eventually rebel.

title: England Beats Denmark for a Spot in Euro 2020 Final
summary: Harry Kane's extra-time goal gave the Three Lions a 2-1 win and a first major tournament final in 55 years. LONDON-For one fraction of a second, England's major tournament fate seemed set to turn again on a missed penalty kick.

title: Tropical Storm Elsa Makes Landfall in Florida on Path Up East Coast
summary: Forecasters say Elsa is expected to track along Mid-Atlantic states up to New Jersey. Tropical Storm Elsa swept inland Wednesday after making landfall along the Florida Gulf Coast, bringing high winds, heavy rain and storm surges.

summary: Resume Subscription. KABUL-Afghanistan's professional class of men and women, part of a generation that came of age under the shield of the U.S. military, are weighing the danger of rapidly advancing Taliban forces. Many are packing their bags.

title: Biden Pitches Child-Care, Education Plan as Democrats Debate Size
summary: Democrats haven't yet agreed on how much the package should cost; nor are they aligned on how much of it should be paid for. WASHINGTON-President Biden sought to rally public support for a multitrillion-dollar education and child-care plan at the core of his domestic-policy agenda, as Democrats in Congress wrestle with disagreements over the size and scope of the package.

title: Julian Assange Wouldn't Be Held in Supermax Jail, U.S. Assures U.K.
summary: Washington makes assurances to Britain in bid to secure Assange's trial on espionage charges in U.S.. LONDON-The U.S. government has given assurances to the U.K. that Julian Assange wouldn't be held under the strictest maximum-security conditions if extradited to the U.S., a concession aimed at resolving Washington's yearslong battle to put the WikiLeaks founder on trial on espionage charges.

summary: The Russell 2000 index has shot up 49% since the end of September. Small-cap stocks have been on a tear since last fall, and some investors expect them to keep booming.

title: Trump Sues Facebook, Twitter, Google to Restore Social-Media Accounts
summary: The former president remains suspended from most social-media platforms following the Jan. 6 riots in the U.S. Capitol. Former President Donald Trump has sued Facebook , Twitter and Google, seeking to restore his online profile after he was suspended from most social-media platforms following the Jan. 6 riots in the U.S. Capitol.

title: Air Force Found Largely Responsible for Texas Church Shooting
summary: Military branch failed to enter the gunman's criminal history into federal background check database used for gun purchases, judge finds. A federal judge ruled that the U.S. Air Force bears most of the responsibility for the 2017 mass shooting at a church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, because it failed to enter the shooter's criminal history into a federal background check database used for gun purchases.

title: Two ATF Agents, Chicago Police Officer Shot During Undercover Operation
summary: The shootings follow a violent holiday weekend when 100 people were shot and 18 murdered. CHICAGO-Two federal agents and a Chicago police officer were shot during an undercover operation Wednesday, following a deadly holiday weekend where 100 people were shot and 18 were killed.

summary: Thousands of healthcare and frontline employees marched in lower Manhattan despite heat. Thousands of healthcare and frontline workers marched in New York City on Wednesday in a ticker-tape parade honoring their work during the Covid-19 pandemic.

summary: Resume Subscription. Don Wiegand was just 17 years old when he made a handshake agreement with his father to buy his future home: an abandoned slaughterhouse his family owned in Chesterfield, Mo.

title: 'Nivola: Sandscapes' Review: Innovations From Italy
summary: Head to the Magazzino in Cold Spring, N.Y., and revel in the Italian artist's innovative sandscast reliefs, concrete sculptures, and rarely-seen architectural maquettes.

title: Rio Tinto Taps Former Unilever Compliance Officer for Top Legal Post
summary: The appointment comes as the mining company's current chief legal officer prepares to depart for Swiss banking giant UBS Group. Rio Tinto PLC has recruited a former compliance officer for Unilever PLC and Nestlé SA to serve as its chief legal officer, overseeing compliance issues for a company that has been at the center of high-stakes legal battles and reputational crises in recent years.

title: Is This the Summer of the Men's Tank Top?
summary: From European runways to Manhattan sidewalks, the popularity of bicep-baring tank tops is surging. Here, why some guys are keen to show a little skin, and how to wear the sleeveless trend-if you dare.. THIS IS SHAPING up to be the summer of skin in men's fashion. During last month's men's runway presentations in Europe, Fendi showed skimpy, navel-flashing crop tops, and Prada sent out bare-chested models in barely there shorts. Outside the always-dramatic high-fashion sphere, young men with day jobs that are not modeling are also brandishing some skin. Thigh-highlighting 5-inch inseam shorts, a style perpetuated by users on TikTok, remain commonplace in urban enclaves. And this summer, the revealing male tank top-a longtime staple of men's wardrobes-is surging with a new vitality.

title: Fed Officials See Earlier End for Bond Buying
summary: June meeting minutes show how officials have been surprised by a stronger-than-expected surge in price pressures as the economy reopens. Federal Reserve officials suggested that they might need to pull back their support for the economy sooner than they had anticipated because of stronger-than-expected growth this year.

title: Your Next Car May Anticipate Your Needs-and Let You Add Features on the Fly
summary: From peppier engines for road trips to heated steering wheels in winter, auto makers are developing intelligent vehicles that spot motorists' wants and let them subscribe to options after the sale. Author

title: What to Watch: 10 Movies and Shows to Stream This Week
summary: Marvel's 'Black Widow' hits Disney+, the romance 'Virgin River' is on Netflix and where to find Richard Donner films like 'The Goonies' and 'Superman'. Among the monsters appearing on screen this week are fuzzy, friendly ones who try to make children laugh; Soviet-era villains who train children to kill; and a few wielding axes (and worse) at summer camp in the '70s. Here's how to stream them-as well as a comfy romantic drama.

title: NYC's Democrats Choose a Crime Fighter for Mayor
summary: Refunding the police is the issue of 2021.. Because lives matter, New York City Democrats have decided that Gotham's next mayor should be a former cop. Like the residents of other U.S. locales suffering pandemic violence following the political left's successful 2020 campaign against law enforcement, New Yorkers are voting to refund the police. The latest news follows a Republican mayoral nomination for the founder of the Guardian Angels. There is finally bipartisan agreement in New York City: The next mayor must enable police to protect the citizenry.

title: Adams Celebrates Victory in NYC Democratic Mayoral Primary
summary: The former police officer vowed to stem violent crime, while his top two opponents in the primary conceded the race. A day after winning the New York City Democratic mayoral primary, Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams vowed to stem rising crime, improve policing and expand education funding if he prevails in the general election in the fall.

title: Backyard Greenhouses Are Growing on Homeowners
summary: These glass outbuildings offer a functional yet beautiful space for gardeners and plant aficionados, especially during the pandemic. Known for blistering summers, the Pacific Coast of British Columbia also grows chilly when the planting season arrives. Emily Yewchuk's desire to construct a greenhouse took hold when seedlings monopolized her kitchen and dining room just as the pandemic hit in March 2020.

title: Hospitals Pressure Employees to Get Vaccinated as Covid-19 Variants Spread
summary: Mandates have met resistance, including legal action. Some hospitals are starting to mandate workers get Covid-19 vaccines as new immunizations flag and variants of the virus spread nationwide, spurring pushback from employees.

title: Biden Builds on Trump's Use of Investment Review Panel to Take On China
summary: Cfius is being empowered to assess more foreign investment threats. WASHINGTON-A low-profile government committee that reviews business deals for national security concerns is receiving expanded emphasis as part of the Biden administration's plan to compete with China.

title: Software Firm at Center of Ransomware Attack Warned of Cyber Flaw in April
summary: President Biden is meeting officials to discuss recent attacks, including latest affecting hundreds of organizations around the world. WASHINGTON-The software company linked to a massive ransomware spree that began last week and has impacted hundreds of organizations across the globe was notified in early April of a cybersecurity vulnerability used in the attack, according to the Dutch security researcher group that discovered the issue.

title: Disaster in Afghanistan Was Foreseeable
summary: America should never again enter a war without the commitment to win.. Afghanistan is another in a long series of U.S. wars without victory, including Korea, Vietnam and Iraq ("Disaster Looms in Afghanistan," Review & Outlook, June 25). In these wars, the U.S. has chosen not to do what is necessary to win decisively. That is why they dragged on for years, consuming lives and treasure without achieving victory.

title: Don't Get Too Clever-Preserve the Filibuster
summary: The passage of any law creates parties with a vested interest in maintaining it and resisting repeal.. F.H. Buckley argues that flaws in a law are seen more clearly in hindsight than foresight, so "Conservatives Should Oppose the Filibuster" (op-ed, June 28). He'd like a procedure that would allow a repeal of a law with 51 instead of 60 Senate votes.

title: How to Serve Blind and Visually Impaired Children
summary: One of the greatest challenges is the proper diagnosis of conditions.. "The Boy Who Learned to See-and What He Teaches Us About Vision" (Review, June 19) touches the tip of the iceberg when it comes to empowering the blind and visually impaired to achieve their potential. One of the greatest challenges facing organizations serving children with visual impairments is the proper diagnosis of conditions and the development of curricula that will expand their personal independence.

title: Measuring Diversity and Segregation in U.S. Cities
summary: Neighborhoods in our most diverse cities tend not to reflect that rich diversity.. Judge Glock's op-ed "An Advocacy Group Spins Diversity as Evidence of 'Segregation'" (June 30) claims that our study's findings are misleading because our preferred measure of segregation "makes cities that have become more diverse look as if they are getting more segregated." This critique is based on an erroneous premise. It is incorrect to review our list of the most segregated cities and metro areas and determine that, because these cities are becoming more diverse, our measure of segregation was capturing only that growing diversity.

title: Gates Foundation Reveals Plan in Case Co-Chairs Can't Work Together
summary: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to add trustees; under a private agreement, Ms. French Gates would resign if after two years either she or Bill Gates decides they can no longer work together. The Gates Foundation said that Melinda French Gates could eventually depart from its leadership if she and Bill Gates determine they can't work together, as the philanthropy laid out plans for its future oversight.

title: Putin Tests Biden's Cyber Vow
summary: When a U.S. President draws a clear red line, he has to enforce it.. Barack Obama's misadventures in Syria showed that a President shouldn't draw red lines he isn't willing to enforce. President Biden hasn't been afraid to talk tough and set expectations with Vladimir Putin, but will Mr. Biden enforce his own red lines?

title: Fintech Wise Makes Strong Debut in London
summary: Money-transfer fintech hit market value of more than $12 billion, giving a boost to London tech scene. Wise PLC's shares made a strong trading debut in London Wednesday, as investors bet on the online money-transfer service's ability to win business from established banks.

title: Looking for a Friend Without Benefits? Try Match, Bumble and Tinder.
summary: Millennials and members of Generation Z increased their use of dating apps to make platonic friends during the pandemic; 'now we all have these big life moments together'. When Jessica Johnson opened new Tinder, Bumble and Hinge accounts at the same time last year, she wasn't looking for romance. She's made it clear on the sites that she is happily married.

summary: Employers are clamoring for workers at hotels, restaurants and other services businesses as the pandemic eases. The number of job openings held at record levels headed into the summer as employers sought to fill positions from a limited pool of workers.

summary: Resume Subscription. In a small Missouri town roughly 40 miles west of St. Louis, a lavish property that includes a 20,000-square-foot home, stables, a private chapel, a sports field and more is seeking $20 million.

title: Daily Covid-19 Deaths in Indonesia Nearly Double as Delta Variant Drives Surge
summary: The healthcare system is crumbling in the largely unvaccinated country, which reported its highest single-day tally of new infections on Wednesday. SINGAPORE-Deaths in Indonesia from Covid-19 rose sharply on Wednesday, with reported daily fatalities nearly double the number from two days ago, as the fast-spreading Delta variant of the coronavirus overwhelms the largely unvaccinated country's healthcare system.

title: A Big Estate In Rural Missouri
summary: Outside St. Louis, this property comes with a 20,000-square-foot home, a resort-style pool, stables and a private chapel.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Ranked-Choice Voting Is Bad for Everyone
summary: It appeals to progressives because it allows them to vote twice-once for show and once for real.. When it comes to counting votes, America's political parties want to keep or gain their own advantage. The public interest, however, demands a nonpartisan method. No neutral method has yet been devised that merely elicits the people's will without twisting it one way or another. Ranked-choice voting is an attempt that has its own twist and will make elections worse for both parties.

title: Don't Worry Too Much About the Inflation Surge
summary: We may be stuck with inflation above 2%-maybe even above 3%-for a while.. If you're worried about a return to the double-digit inflation of the 1970s and '80s, relax. There is a lot of angst these days as a result of the stunning 5% inflation rate (for the year ending May 2021) in the last consumer-price index release. We haven't seen a reading that high in 13 years, but the huge supply shocks of the double-digit days aren't present, and the Federal Reserve won't let inflation soar. It is certainly possible, however, that inflation will linger above the Fed's 2% target for a while.

title: Amtrak to Spend $7 Billion to Upgrade Passenger Trains
summary: New railcars built by Siemens in California will have improved seating and modern amenities. WASHINGTON-Amtrak said Wednesday it will spend $7.3 billion to replace aging railcars and locomotives, adding hundreds of new coaches with more comfortable seating, improved disabled access, individual power outlets and "a more contemporary food service experience."

summary: The Japanese holding company looks to bolster its offerings beyond advertising. Japanese advertising giant Dentsu Group Inc. said it would acquire the customer experience and commerce agency LiveArea from e-commerce company PFSweb Inc. for about $250 million.

Amazon.com Inc.'s proposed acquisition of film studio MGM would ordinarily provoke little antitrust concern. MGM's share of box office receipts is tiny and Amazon's entertainment footprint is relatively small.

summary: Outlook for the global economy and financial markets depends in part on whether you subtract cash from debt. title: Travel Is Bouncing Back Strong, and Airlines Are Racing to Keep Up

summary: Upbeat, bouncy songs by BTS, Doja Cat and Dua Lipa are dominating the charts this season, along with moody retro jams. Summer is high time for escapist pop music-and this year the appetite for carefree tunes could be greater in the wake of Covid-19 and the end of lockdowns.

summary: The state's grid operator is seeking to secure extra megawatts as a hot summer threatens to strain regional power supplies. California's power-grid manager is taking emergency steps to secure extra electricity as a hot, dry summer increases the risk of blackouts.

summary: Its leaders warn of the threat from Beijing, but their budgets suggest otherwise.. U.S. defense leaders have a problem: What they say doesn't line up with what they do. CAIRO-The container ship that blocked the Suez Canal for days earlier this year set sail Wednesday after its owners reached a multimillion-dollar compensation deal with Egyptian authorities for its release, ending a monthslong saga involving passage through a critical global trade route.

title: Taliban Attack on Afghan City Allows 200 Prison Inmates to Escape

title: Democrats Split Over Measures to Cut Drug Prices
summary: Those seeking bipartisan measure say empowering Medicare to negotiate for lower prices could hurt innovation. WASHINGTON-Democrats are debating whether to fold an effort to cut drug prices-by allowing Medicare to negotiate-into a budget package or try to pass the measure on its own.

title: The Business School Lesson at the Tour de France
summary: A professional rider is attempting a do-it-himself race through the mountains and onto Paris. Is this a model for the future of sports?. The Australian cyclist Lachlan Morton is amid a throwback Tour de France-an old-school version of the race in which he rides alone, repairs his own bike, seeks out his own food, and pretty much fends for himself all the way around the countryside to Paris.

title: R.E.M.'s Michael Stipe's Radical Vulnerability
summary: With the publication of his latest photography book, the musician talks about the elusive nature of fame and masculinity while sharing some of his favorite mementos.. As an artist, Michael Stipe is, in his words, "uncategorizable": He's a photographer, a musician, a stage designer and a film producer, among other things. When discussing his art in all its forms, Stipe speaks with reverence of the women who have influenced it, from his mother and his multiple goddaughters to Patti Smith, Liza Minnelli and Greta Thunberg. His own name is synonymous with R.E.M., the now-dissolved rock band from Athens, Georgia, that Stipe helmed until 2011. Their top-selling single "Losing My Religion" became an unlikely, mandolin-led anthem of angst for an entire generation in the early '90s, catapulting the group onto the global stage.

title: Summer Shoes and Bags for Staying Chic in the Heat
summary: Matching accessories in woven textures and natural fibers keep things light and airy.. In hot weather, accessories can be a simple way to add polish to a casual summer outfit. Pairing a bag and shoe can create a pulled-together look-especially when the focus is on natural fibers. In the late '60s and '70s, Jane Birkin made it seem effortless with her T-shirt, jeans and straw market basket. And on the spring runways, Etro, Dior, Fendi and Bottega Veneta gave woven materials their moment in the sun, bringing raffia, wicker and cord to light. Tie on some espadrilles to go with a wicker Ulla Johnson bottle bag, ready to carry a chilled Beaujolais to the park. A nautical-printed Etro heel plays off the brand's bucket bag. And for a beach-to-street pairing, Longchamp's mesh market bag works well with Tod's cord, leather and raffia flat, which also converts into a slide. -Lizzy Wholley

title: Didi's China Probe Adds to Business Challenges at Home and Abroad
summary: Tech giant under regulatory scrutiny is struggling to move beyond its dependence on ride-hailing in China. summary: Games organizers are reconsidering their decision to allow some local fans, among other tough new Covid-mitigation measures for participants. title: Ketchum, Idaho, Has Plenty of Available Jobs, but Workers Can't Afford Housing
summary: Resume Subscription. KETCHUM, Idaho-Ethan McKee-Bakos has had no trouble finding work since he moved to this upscale mountain town last February, earning $60,000 a year from two jobs. But Mr. McKee-Bakos spent nearly six weeks living out of his SUV in the nearby Sawtooth National Forest, unable to afford rent for a condo.

title: American Stocks Have Lost Their Exceptionalism (Except Big Tech)
summary: The nation's banks and industrial equities now move more closely with foreign share prices than with U.S. growth stocks. American companies have a lot in common. They tend to have lots of exposure to the U.S. economy, have similar demand for their shares through buying and selling of broad indexes of the U.S. market and, of course, are subject to the same regulations, laws and governance.

title: Owner of Forever 21, JCPenney Files to Go Public
summary: Authentic Brands scooped up battered retail brands before and during pandemic. The owner of downtrodden retail brands including JCPenney and Forever 21 plans to sell shares to the public, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Texas Teacher's Neil Randall Says He's Unfazed by High Valuations
summary: The director of private equity at one of Texas's largest state pensions still sees promise in co-investments and secondary deals despite high valuations. The rebound in private-equity activity during the first half of the year has posed new challenges for backers of private-equity funds even as it has opened up fresh opportunities. As part of our series on the state of private equity so far in 2021, WSJ Pro Private Equity caught up with Neil Randall, director of private equity at the Teacher Retirement System of Texas, to learn more about how the roughly $176.9 billion pension manager is positioning its private-equity portfolio. Responses have been edited for clarity and style.

title: Robinhood's Debut Clouded by SEC Scrutiny of Payment for Order Flow
summary: The practice provided 81% of the online brokerage's first-quarter revenue. Robinhood Markets Inc. is on a collision course with regulators over a controversial practice that generates most of its revenue, as the online brokerage gears up for a highly anticipated initial public offering.

title: Banner Quarter From Facebook, Google Could Mask Apple's Bite
summary: Online ad titans will benefit from easy comparisons in second quarter, but the ongoing rollout of Apple's iOS could still hit results. Second-quarter results coming up in a few weeks from ad giants Facebook and Google parent Alphabet could suggest the bark of Apple 's iOS privacy changes was worse than their bite. But investors shouldn't get too comfortable: The bulk of the impact is likely still to come.

title: Big Tech Startups Spring Up in South Korea
summary: They are thriving even as big technology companies face intensifying scrutiny elsewhere. South Korea is becoming a hotbed of big technology startups.

title: Photos: The Surfside Condo Disaster
summary: Florida officials press ahead with efforts to find survivors of the Champlain Towers South collapse.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: SoftBank Backs Facial-Recognition Startup Despite Privacy Concerns
summary: Israeli firm AnyVision to use $235 million investment to expand in U.S.. SoftBank Group Corp. is leading an investment in AnyVision Interactive Technologies Ltd. that values the facial-recognition company at over $1 billion, according to a person familiar with the matter, underscoring its commitment to the technology despite pushback over privacy concerns.

title: Coal Shows Its Staying Power as Economies Bounce Back
summary: Surging electricity use and higher natural-gas prices are giving coal new life despite its environmental drawbacks. Coal use is surging in some of the world's largest economies as electricity demand rebounds from the pandemic, illustrating the challenges to countries looking to wean themselves off the dirty but reliable fossil fuel.

title: Bank Stocks in Europe Zoom Higher, Rewarding Bargain Hunters
summary: European bank shares have recouped pandemic losses, generating big gains for investors who swooped in last year. European banks are among the stock market's top performers, making winners out of the investors who backed them when many wouldn't touch them during the pandemic.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine-Related Blood Clots Linked to Amino Acids in New Study
summary: Canadian researchers zero in on molecular details of antibody clusters following AstraZeneca shots. Canadian researchers say they have pinpointed a handful of amino acids targeted by key antibodies in the blood of some people who received AstraZeneca PLC's Covid-19 vaccine, offering fresh clues to what causes rare blood clots associated with the shot.

title: Chinese EV Maker XPeng Makes Debut in Hong Kong
summary: With uncertainty clouding Chinese listings in U.S., rival to Tesla and NIO obtained dual-primary listing and raised $1.8 billion. Chinese electric-vehicle maker XPeng Inc. made its debut on Hong Kong's stock exchange on Wednesday, wrapping up a listing that brings it closer to investors in China and offers it insurance against the risk of being kicked off U.S. markets.

title: YouTube Algorithm Directs Viewers to False, Sexualized Videos, Study Finds
summary: More than 70% of videos flagged by study participants as objectionable were recommended by YouTube, according to Mozilla. YouTube has instituted many changes over the past year to limit the problematic videos it recommends to viewers. A new study suggests the repairs have a way to go.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: World's First Covid-19 Vaccine Swap Sends Israel's Expiring Supply to South Korea
summary: South Korea gets 700,000 Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines now and will later send identical number back to Israel. Israel sent about 700,000 expiring Pfizer -BioNTech shots to South Korea, in what is the world's first Covid-19 vaccine swap.

title: Samsung Expects 53% Increase in Operating Profit
summary: Company is lifted by strong demand for memory chips that offset weaker device sales-hurt by component shortages. SEOUL- Samsung Electronics Co. expects a 53% rise in operating profit for the second quarter, lifted by strong demand for memory chips that offset weaker device sales hurt by component shortages.

title: How Mutations Have Shaped the Covid-19 Pandemic
summary: The Delta variant is rapidly taking over the U.S. Here is a look at how SARS-CoV-2 has evolved, frustrating efforts to contain it. The Delta variant of the Covid-19 virus is quickly becoming the dominant type of coronavirus in the U.S., making it one of most aggressive variants to take hold in the country.

title: Anti-Inflammatory Drugs Recommended for Some Covid-19 Patients
summary: The recommended drugs, Actemra and Kevzara, target the haywire immune response to infections. The World Health Organization recommended that certain hospitalized Covid-19 patients be given a type of anti-inflammatory drug found to reduce the risk of death by 13% in the sickest patients when taken in combination with steroids.

title: New York City Mayoral Race: Eric Adams Wins Democratic Primary
summary: The results showed that the former police officer received 50.5% of the nearly 938,000 votes. Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams, a former police officer who made public safety the centerpiece of his campaign, won New York City's Democratic mayoral primary, according to election results released Tuesday.
